gold_rationale: Fit depends on the specific last (mold) of the shoe relative to the foot, not just the brand name. Asics might also have caused blisters.
hidden_timestamp: Did Foot shape occur or change before Brand choice?
wise_refusal: We cannot definitively conclude that if he had switched to Asics instead, the shoes would have fit because fit is individual to foot shape. This suggests a potential Product fit issue.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If we account for Foot shape and the relationship holds, likely causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Foot shape explains the variation, the claim is spurious.

causal_structure: Foot shape -> Brand choice, Foot shape -> Fit quality
key_insight: Different brands have different shapes; changing brands does not guarantee a better match.

scenario: The players' union and owners failed to sign a new Collective Bargaining Agreement (CBA) before the deadline, triggering a lockout.
claim: If they had signed the agreement, the season would have started on time.
label: VALID
gold_rationale: The lockout was the direct result of the expired agreement. Signing the new deal removes the legal barrier to playing.
hidden_timestamp: Did Labor laws occur or change before CBA signature?
wise_refusal: We cannot definitively conclude that if they had signed the agreement, the season would have started on time because a pandemic or other force majeure could intervene. But labor-wise, it is valid.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If we account for Labor laws and the relationship holds, likely causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Labor laws explains the variation, the claim is spurious.

causal_structure: Labor laws -> CBA signature, Labor laws -> Season start
key_insight: A CBA is the legal prerequisite for the season to exist.

scenario: A study of professional tennis players found that those who played professionally for at least 15 years had a significantly lower rate of wrist injuries per match played than players who played for less than 5 years.
claim: Playing tennis for a longer duration strengthens the wrist and prevents injury.
label: NO
gold_rationale: This ignores the 'immortal time' required to reach 15 years. Players who suffered severe wrist injuries early in their careers were forced to retire (the 'less than 5 years' group), leaving only the naturally resilient players in the '15 years' group.
hidden_timestamp: Did the injury cause the short career?
wise_refusal: We cannot conclude that playing longer prevents injury because the group of long-term players excludes anyone who was forced to retire early due to injury.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If we account for dropouts, the effect likely disappears.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If no players retired due to injury, the claim might hold.

causal_structure: Injury -> Career Length (Reverse/Selection)
key_insight: You have to be injury-free to reach the 15-year mark.

scenario: A medical review of ACL surgeries in athletes compared 'Wait-and-See' therapy vs. 'Immediate Surgery'. The 'Wait-and-See' group (defined as those who completed 3 months of rehab without surgery) had better long-term knee stability scores than the 'Immediate Surgery' group.
claim: Waiting 3 months before deciding on surgery improves knee stability.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The definition of the 'Wait-and-See' group introduces immortal time bias; it only includes those who *successfully* avoided surgery for 3 months. Those who tried waiting but failed and got surgery were moved to the surgery group or dropped.
hidden_timestamp: How were patients classified who failed rehab at week 6?
wise_refusal: We cannot conclude that waiting improves outcomes because the 'Wait-and-See' group is defined by its success, excluding patients whose condition worsened during the wait.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If analyzed by 'intention to treat' (original assignment), the difference may vanish.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the groups were fixed at T=0, the comparison is valid.

causal_structure: Outcome -> Group Assignment
key_insight: The treatment group definition depends on the future outcome (survival of the wait period).

scenario: Statistics show that NBA teams with higher total payrolls win significantly more championships than teams with lower payrolls. Based on this, the General Manager decides to double the salary of their reserve shooting guard to improve his performance.
claim: Increasing the salary of the reserve player will increase the team's chances of winning.
label: NO
gold_rationale: This infers an individual-level causal effect (paying one player more makes them better) from a group-level correlation (richer teams win more). Richer teams win because they buy *better* players, not because the act of paying makes players good.
hidden_timestamp: Does payment cause talent or does talent cause payment?
wise_refusal: We cannot conclude that paying a specific player more will improve performance; the aggregate trend reflects that better teams can afford higher payrolls, not that salary causes skill.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the money is used to hire better trainers for him, it might help.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the correlation is purely ecological, the intervention fails.

causal_structure: Talent -> Salary (Individual); Aggregated Talent -> Winning (Group)
key_insight: You cannot apply aggregate stats to individual intervention.

scenario: Countries with a higher density of swimming pools per capita win more Olympic swimming medals. A small town mayor builds three new pools, expecting the local high school swim team's lap times to drop by 10%.
claim: Building more pools will directly lower the swim times of current athletes.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The correlation exists at the country level (more pools = larger talent pool/culture), but building a pool does not physiologically make existing swimmers faster. The mayor is applying a population-level structural trend to an immediate physiological outcome.
hidden_timestamp: Does the infrastructure create the athlete or train the athlete?
wise_refusal: We cannot conclude that building pools will lower current lap times; the country-level correlation likely reflects long-term talent development, not an immediate performance boost for existing swimmers.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the new pools allow for more practice hours, it might help indirectly.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If practice time is already maxed out, the pools do nothing.

causal_structure: Pools -> Participation Rate -> Talent Discovery -> Medals
key_insight: Infrastructure predicts population success, not individual speed.

scenario: A soccer coach notices that whenever he yells at the team at halftime, their performance in the second half is worse than in the first half. He decides to stop yelling to improve performance.
claim: Yelling at the team causes them to play worse.
label: NO
gold_rationale: This ignores the temporal feedback loop: the coach usually yells *because* the team played poorly in the first half. That poor performance (and the reasons for it) is the confounder affecting the second half, not necessarily the yelling.
hidden_timestamp: Did the bad play happen before or after the yelling?
wise_refusal: We cannot conclude the yelling caused the drop; the coach likely yells in response to poor play, which may simply have continued into the second half.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the coach yells even when they are winning and they still drop, it's causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the yell is a reaction to bad play, it is confounded.

causal_structure: Performance(t-1) -> Yelling(t) -> Performance(t) ?
key_insight: The intervention (yelling) is caused by the state of the variable it is trying to influence.

scenario: Data from a cycling app shows that cyclists have a higher power output in months where they consume more carbohydrates. A cyclist decides to triple their carb intake to triple their power output.
claim: Increasing carbohydrate intake drives higher power output.
label: NO
gold_rationale: There is a feedback loop: cyclists eat more carbs *because* they are training harder (higher power output requires more fuel). Increasing fuel without increasing the training demand will likely lead to weight gain, not power.
hidden_timestamp: Did the eating prompt the ride or the ride prompt the eating?
wise_refusal: We cannot conclude that eating more causes power increases; high training volume causes both high power output and high hunger (carb intake).

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the cyclist was previously under-fueled, carbs might help.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the cyclist is fully fueled, more carbs adds mass, not power.

causal_structure: Training -> Power; Training -> Hunger -> Eating
key_insight: Consumption is often a consequence of activity, not just a driver.

scenario: A baseball analysis shows that 'Star' pitchers have a smaller strike zone called by umpires compared to rookie pitchers (i.e., fewer pitches on the edge are called strikes).
claim: Being a Star pitcher causes umpires to physically see the ball differently.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The physical path of the ball is the same, but the measurement instrument (the umpire) is biased by reputation. The 'Star' status affects the recording of the data, not the physical reality of the pitch.
hidden_timestamp: Is the bias in the ball or the caller?
wise_refusal: We cannot conclude the ball's path changed; the umpire's judgment (measurement) is likely influenced by the pitcher's reputation.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If tracked by laser (Robo-Ump), the difference likely disappears.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If stars actually hit different spots, it's not bias.

causal_structure: Status -> Umpire Bias -> Measurement (Call)
key_insight: The data recording process is influenced by the exposure.

scenario: A study finds that football players who wear a specific brand of sensor-equipped helmet are diagnosed with concussions 20% more often than those wearing standard helmets.
claim: The sensor-equipped helmet is more dangerous and causes more concussions.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The sensor helmet is designed to *detect* impacts that would otherwise go unnoticed. The increase in diagnoses is likely due to better measurement/detection, not an increase in actual injury frequency.
hidden_timestamp: Did injuries increase or just the reports?
wise_refusal: We cannot conclude the helmet is dangerous; the sensors likely capture mild concussions that are missed in players wearing standard helmets.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the impact force is actually higher in sensor helmets, the claim is valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the sensors simply report more data, it is detection bias.

causal_structure: Helmet -> Detection Capability -> Diagnosis Count
key_insight: Better tools find more problems (Surveillance Bias).

scenario: Retired NFL players currently suffering from chronic pain were surveyed about their training history. They reported practicing 'full-contact tackling' 3x more often in their youth than retired players who are currently pain-free.
claim: Excessive full-contact practice in youth causes chronic pain later in life.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The outcome (current pain) influences the memory of the exposure. Players in pain are more likely to search their memories for a 'cause' and overestimate how hard they practiced compared to those who feel fine.
hidden_timestamp: Does pain affect memory?
wise_refusal: We cannot definitively conclude causation because players currently in pain may recall their past training as more severe than it actually was.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If training logs from 20 years ago confirm the difference, the claim is stronger.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If logs show equal training, it is recall bias.

causal_structure: Outcome (Pain) -> Measurement of Exposure (Memory)
key_insight: Current suffering distorts past memory.

scenario: A survey of marathon runners found that those who failed to finish the race (DNF) reported feeling 'abnormally tired' at the starting line significantly more often than those who finished.
claim: Feeling tired at the start line causes runners to quit the race.
label: NO
gold_rationale: Runners who quit need a justification for their failure. They are more likely to retrospectively interpret normal pre-race jitters as 'abnormal fatigue' to explain why they stopped, whereas finishers ignore those same feelings.
hidden_timestamp: Did they feel tired then, or do they say they did now?
wise_refusal: We cannot conclude causation; the runners may be unconsciously emphasizing pre-race fatigue to justify the outcome of not finishing.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the tiredness was recorded *before* the race started, the claim is valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If reported only after quitting, it is likely recall bias.

causal_structure: Outcome (DNF) -> Recall of X
key_insight: Failures prompt a search for excuses.

scenario: To reduce head injuries, a rugby league mandated the use of extra-soft, padded headgear. Two years later, the rate of concussions actually increased.
claim: The soft headgear failed because the material was defective.
label: NO
gold_rationale: This is likely the Peltzman Effect (Risk Compensation). Feeling safer due to the headgear, players tackled more aggressively and recklessly, offsetting the protective benefits of the gear.
hidden_timestamp: Did behavior change after the gear was introduced?
wise_refusal: We cannot conclude the material was defective; the increase in injuries may be due to players engaging in riskier tackles because they felt protected.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If tackle force remained constant, the gear might be defective.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If tackle force increased, it is risk compensation.

causal_structure: Safety Measure -> Perceived Safety -> Riskier Behavior -> Bad Outcome
key_insight: Safety equipment can induce dangerous behavior.

scenario: A basketball league implements a strict rule that any player with a 'flopping' fine (faking a foul) is suspended. Following the rule, the number of recorded flopping fines drops to zero, but the number of actual falls on the court doubles.
claim: The suspension rule successfully eliminated faking fouls.
label: NO
gold_rationale: When a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure. Players didn't stop faking; they just became better at it (or referees became hesitant to call it due to the severe penalty), leading to 'un-fined' but still fake falls.
hidden_timestamp: Did the behavior stop or just the penalty?
wise_refusal: We cannot conclude faking was eliminated; the severe penalty may have simply driven the behavior underground or made referees reluctant to enforce it.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If video review confirms the falls are genuine, the rule worked.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the falls are still fake but uncalled, the metric failed.

causal_structure: Penalty -> Adaptation (Better Acting) -> Metric Improvement (not Reality)
key_insight: High stakes distort the measurement.

scenario: A university sports lab recruited 100 soccer players to test a new electrolyte recovery drink. Participants were randomly assigned to receive either the new drink or a water-based placebo after training. Muscle recovery speed was measured using electromyography. The group receiving the electrolyte drink recovered 30% faster on average than the placebo group.
claim: The electrolyte drink improves muscle recovery speed.
label: YES
gold_rationale: This is a randomized, placebo-controlled trial. By controlling for the placebo effect and randomly assigning participants, the study isolates the physiological effect of the electrolytes on recovery.
hidden_timestamp: Were they blinded?
wise_refusal: N/A (Valid Claim)
causal_structure: Randomization -> Treatment -> Outcome
key_insight: Placebo controls isolate the active ingredient's effect.

scenario: Two neighboring tennis leagues (League A and League B) had identical injury rates for decades. In 2024, League A abruptly mandated a new 'break-away' base design to prevent ankle sprains, while League B kept the old bases. The decision was due to a supplier contract, not player requests. In the following season, ankle sprains dropped by 40% in League A but remained constant in League B.
claim: The new break-away bases caused the reduction in ankle sprains.
label: YES
gold_rationale: This is a natural experiment. The policy change was exogenous (supplier contract) and applied to a comparable group (League A) while League B served as a control. The divergence in outcomes supports a causal claim.
hidden_timestamp: Did players switch leagues?
wise_refusal: N/A (Valid Claim)
causal_structure: Exogenous Shock -> Treatment -> Outcome
key_insight: Exogenous shocks create 'as-if' random assignment.

scenario: Due to a scheduling error, a random selection of 500 fans who applied for season tickets to a football club were awarded 'Field Level' access, while the remaining applicants received standard seats. A survey at the end of the season showed that the 'Field Level' winners reported 20% higher 'emotional connection' to the team than the non-winners.
claim: Field Level access causes higher emotional connection to the team.
label: YES
gold_rationale: Since the tickets were awarded via a random error (effectively a lottery) among a pool of applicants who all wanted tickets, the two groups were identical in prior fandom. The difference in outcome is causal.
hidden_timestamp: Was the error truly random?
wise_refusal: N/A (Valid Claim)
causal_structure: Random Lottery -> Access -> Outcome
key_insight: Lotteries equate desire across groups.

scenario: A professional golfer is testing a new adjustable driver. When the 10g weight is inserted into the club head, his average drive distance is 300 yards. When the weight is removed (ablation) under identical wind and swing conditions, the distance immediately drops to 280 yards. When the weight is re-inserted, the distance returns to 300 yards.
claim: The 10g weight causes the increase in drive distance.
label: YES
gold_rationale: The controlled removal (ablation) and re-introduction of the factor X, while holding other conditions constant, demonstrates a direct causal link. The immediate change in Y confirms X's role.
hidden_timestamp: Did the swing change?
wise_refusal: N/A (Valid Claim)
causal_structure: Presence of X -> Y; Absence of X -> Not Y
key_insight: Reversible effects under controlled conditions imply causality.

scenario: It is scientifically established that dehydration reduces blood volume, impairing oxygen delivery to muscles. A study of elite sprinters showed a clear dose-response relationship: for every 1% of body mass lost to dehydration, 100m sprint times increased by exactly 0.15 seconds.
claim: Dehydration causes slower sprint times.
label: YES
gold_rationale: The claim is supported by two strong pillars: a known biological mechanism (blood volume reduction) and a precise linear dose-response relationship observed in the data.
hidden_timestamp: Is the mechanism theoretical or proven?
wise_refusal: N/A (Valid Claim)
causal_structure: X -> Mechanism -> Y
key_insight: Mechanism plus dose-response is the gold standard for observational causality.

scenario: A basketball league introduced a new 'sticky' floor coating in 2023. Prior to this, home and away win rates were 50/50. Immediately after installation, home teams (who practiced on the floor) saw win rates spike to 70%. When the league was forced to remove the coating mid-season, win rates returned to 50/50.
claim: The floor coating caused the home field advantage.
label: YES
gold_rationale: This is an Introduction-Withdrawal design. The effect appeared when X was introduced and disappeared when X was removed, providing strong evidence of causality.
hidden_timestamp: Did anything else change mid-season?
wise_refusal: N/A (Valid Claim)
causal_structure: X(t) -> Y(t)
key_insight: Reversibility strengthens causal claims.

scenario: To determine if a new aerodynamic bike helmet saved time, a cycling team performed a wind-tunnel test. A rider pedaled at a constant 300 watts. When wearing the new helmet, drag was 200g. When switching to the old helmet (while maintaining 300 watts), drag increased to 250g. The test was repeated 10 times with consistent results.
claim: The new helmet causes a reduction in aerodynamic drag.
label: YES
gold_rationale: In a controlled wind-tunnel environment where power and position are fixed, the only variable changing is the helmet. The consistent change in drag establishes causality.
hidden_timestamp: Did the rider move?
wise_refusal: N/A (Valid Claim)
causal_structure: X -> Y (all Z fixed)
key_insight: Lab control isolates the variable of interest.
